problem: How many real numbers are not in the domain of the function $$f(x) = \frac{1}{x-64} + \frac{1}{x^2-64} + \frac{1}{x^3-64}~?$$
solution: A real number $x$ is in the domain of $$f(x) = \frac{1}{x-64} + \frac{1}{x^2-64} + \frac{1}{x^3-64}$$ unless at least one of $x-64$, $x^2-64$, $x^3-64$ is equal to $0$. This occurs for $x=64$, $x=8$, $x=-8$, and $x=4$, so there are $\boxed{4}$ real numbers not in the domain of $f$.
